audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a short, gentle, and calming musical piece, reminiscent of a soft background underscore, which transitions to a male narrator who announces the topic of "Inheritance and mutations". He explains that diseases can be passed down in different ways, with a calm and informative tone. The audio clip concludes with the music fading back in.

The audio begins with a single male speaker describing a Punnett square. He has a clear and informative speaking tone and provides details on how to construct and use the diagram for illustrating inheritance. There is no music or background sound in the audio clip.

The audio clip begins with a male narrator describing how a parent can pass down chromosomes. The tone is informative. There is no background music. Then, the male narrator explains a scenario with chromosomes that have mutations. He continues in a similar tone to explain how the mother and father contribute to the inheritance of the chromosomes, specifying that "the mother passes one copy" and the "father has one chromosome with a mutation in purple."

The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining genetics, mentioning a "50% chance" and "two chromosomes" and detailing how mutations are inherited. He speaks in an informative tone. He explains possible outcomes, including chances for being "born with two chromosomes that carry the mutation" or without "the mutation on either chromosome". He continues to describe a child being "born with one copy of the mutation and one copy of the chromosome without the mutation".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that the Punnett square determines the likelihood of having an affected child. He says that "this likelihood is reset for each pregnancy," so even if a child is affected, the chance of mutation remains the same for future siblings. He concludes by saying that while it's rare for two parents with one mutation each to have four children with two copies of the mutation, "it is still possible."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of genetic mutations and disorders. He then describes types of monogenic disorders and autosomal mutations, giving examples and discussing the probabilities of different inheritance scenarios. His tone is educational and clear.  Light, gentle background music plays throughout, adding a calm, informative mood with its keyboard and synthesized sounds.

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker explaining autosomal dominant diseases, describing how only one copy of the mutation is needed for the disease to manifest and giving the example of achondroplastic dwarfism. He says that the chances of having an affected child are "50%" and breaks down the scenarios, saying that if at least one parent has both copies of an affected gene, "all children will be affected." The speaker's tone is educational and matter-of-fact. He explains further scenarios, noting the overall chance that a child will be affected by the disease is "three in four."

The audio clip features a male speaker explaining how mutations can occur in sex chromosomes, focusing on the differences between male and female chromosome pairings. He says, "men are XY, women are XX." He specifically mentions Y chromosome mutations leading to low sperm counts and their hereditary transmission. The speaker maintains a neutral, informative tone throughout.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing autosomal mutations and X-linked diseases, clarifying how these diseases manifest differently in males and females. He speaks in a clear, informative tone. The clip then segues into a more detailed explanation of X-linked recessive conditions, using hemophilia as an example. The same speaker further explains the roles of X chromosomes in both males and females, and explains how women can be carriers.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the probabilities of X-linked recessive inheritance. He describes cases involving carrier mothers and healthy fathers, non-carrier mothers and affected fathers, an affected mother and affected father, and lastly, a carrier mother and an affected father. The speaker's tone is informative and instructional. No music or background sounds are present.

The audio clip starts with a hopeful and informative female voice, summarizing the information provided. The speaker then directs listeners to "reproductivefacts.org" for more on genetic testing. This is followed by calm and ambient background music, which gently suggests a peaceful environment.
